text: Assuming that you're not doing 2 - you'd have told us wouldn't you? Then it would have to be 1 or 2. So the question becomes what's happened to the traded volume in the markets? If that's gone down it would suggest 1, but if it's remained constant then it suggests that some of the matched bets are now going elsewhere, i.e. 3.

text:
If you don't already, I'd recommend tracking as much as possible around the matching process - total volume matched, volume matched on your selections, liquidity per second around the time you place your bets, the amount of money waiting at the prices you bet on etc.

If you haven't run the strategy for more than a year, one of the causes may be seasonality - although imo the exact immediate cause can only be known by tracking enough data to tell you what's happening around your matching process

text: I wouldn't call this 'normal', based on your previous issues how confident are you that you haven't changed anything? Latency on your tick to trade? etc.

elements.text: I wouldn't call this 'normal', based on your previous issues how confident are you that you haven't changed anything? Latency on your tick to trade? etc.

text: As confident as I can be. My mean placement roundtrip times are within 10 ms of what they were previously. I will dig deeper though as idiocy can never be ruled out.

text:
People come and go all the time, unless it's something easy to see like less activity (not necessarily accompanied by declining vol) then you can't tell what's caused it.
Or it's 3, with a bit of 4. Whoever's been paying you has quit.

I've got a similar situation, but it's something that's been steady wages for 5yrs, on 2 sports, 2 regions, both win and place (ie 8 markets) All faded simultaneously over about 6 weeks and now EV has been flat as a pancake for a month. I'm still trying to find out why.

text: This was not steady - it was as if someone flicked a switch and I dropped from 80%+ match rate to 25% on a particular date and its been the same since. More than likely something I've done myself without realising it. It's minimum stakes and the US markets are wafer thin so probably won't take much to upset the balance.

Not.    But that explains why it's been boom time for my mixed doubles ping pong strategy. :grin:  Wimbledon and big footy can divert some money but Olympic markets aren't big enough to cause a ripple. 

There's usually a silver lining, an enforced revisit isn't necessarily bad thing.

text:
<@UUE6E1LA1> or maybe up <@UBS7QANF3>'s street: How would you go about determining how likely a fall of this sort would be to occur randomly? Match rates are variable by event, so a fall could be string of bad events, these do occur randomly as we all know. What's the right methodology for that?

<@UUE6E1LA1> I know you have the maths - If you've got time I'd be really interested to see that as a worked example.

text: I'm not sure that it is possible to determine really. I mean how do you assign a probability to someone else developing a similar strategy. The US spread is wide - this is a 100% offer price strat so someone could easily be offering better than I am. In all honesty <@UGV299K6H> I would not know where to start in regards to putting a number on it.

text: I think the highest probability explanation is that I've upset something myself. I think  my time is best spent ruling that out first.

elements.text: I think the highest probability explanation is that I've upset something myself. I think  my time is best spent ruling that out first.

text: Must be possible though right? I don't think you need to evidence the narrative aspects of it - IE whether some specific individual might be front running you. Isn't it sufficient to show that there's a change in the frequency of matching that's greater than you would expect to occur randomly? I think many of us struggle to tell what's random and what's not even after a years of doing this. For my own part I assume randomness until that becomes implausible but there must be a better way.

text: It's possible but I would not know where to start with it to be honest. If I could assume that it isn't a mistake at my end, AND the market volumes have not dropped off then the most likely explanation would be someone else putting up better prices than mine. Something I will be able to scrutinise after looking at the first 2 points. It's the nature of the drop though - it is like an overnight step change which is good evidence that something I've done (but can't identify) is the cause of the problem

text: Tricky one, backtesting variations (like asking for less margin)  is unreliable in markets you were present in. But it's impractical to step away for long enough to get a big enough clean sample without you in it..  I end up lowering the latency just enough for test 'me'  to beat what live me did but then that's at best only an indicative bodge.  What happened is knowable, what you should have done instead and into the future might not be.

text: I don't see why you should need any back-testing when you've got your own real results.

elements.text: I don't see why you should need any back-testing when you've got your own real results.

text: Backtests aren't needed to look at what happened, just saying if you want to test variations then your presence can be a factor.

elements.text: Backtests aren't needed to look at what happened, just saying if you want to test variations then your presence can be a factor.

text: Backtests are good - if your backtest for May + June look similar and look good, while your real performance for May matches backtest but June doesn't then likely you've broken something (i.e. you got a bug). If your backtest for June shows similar degradation then it suggests your alpha has degraded (either because some participants have scaled down, someone competitive has entereed etc). It might be a matter of recalibrating some params, or it might be a matter of resting the strategy and backtesting again in a few weeks to see if the breakage was transient or not.

elements.text: Backtests are good - if your backtest for May + June look similar and look good, while your real performance for May matches backtest but June doesn't then likely you've broken something (i.e. you got a bug). If your backtest for June shows similar degradation then it suggests your alpha has degraded (either because some participants have scaled down, someone competitive has entereed etc). It might be a matter of recalibrating some params, or it might be a matter of resting the strategy and backtesting again in a few weeks to see if the breakage was transient or not.

text: plot your tick-to-trade over time, plot your traded volumes versus total volumes etc and look for signs of being out-competed (and also signs of breaking things on your end)

elements.text: plot your tick-to-trade over time, plot your traded volumes versus total volumes etc and look for signs of being out-competed (and also signs of breaking things on your end)
